title: 114_hr470
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015". It includes findings and definitions. The Act, known as the "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015," contains findings stating that certain National Forest System land in Georgia is inefficient to manage or has lost its value for National Forest purposes. The Act authorizes the sale of this land for the public interest, with proceeds used by the Forest Service to purchase land for National Forest purposes in Georgia. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange United States' rights in National Forest System land in Georgia totaling approximately 3,841 acres. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange approximately 3,841 acres of National Forest System land in Georgia. The maps of the land will be available for public inspection until sold or exchanged, and the Secretary may modify boundaries based on land management considerations. Land sold will be conveyed by quitclaim deed. The Secretary may reserve rights-of-way or interests in land sold under this Act for management purposes. Land cannot be sold for less than market value as determined by appraisal. Appraisals must follow federal standards. The Secretary may accept cash equalization payments exceeding 25% of land value in exchanges. The method of sale allows for various options. The Secretary has the authority to sell land through public or private sale, including competitive auctions, and can solicit offers for the sale or exchange of land. The Secretary may also reject offers that are deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. Additionally, the Secretary may engage brokers in the sale process. The Secretary has the authority to use brokers or third parties in the sale of land authorized by the Act and pay reasonable commissions from the proceeds of the sale. The Secretary will deposit sale proceeds in the Sisk Act fund for land acquisition in Georgia without further appropriation. Funds cannot be used to acquire land without owner consent.
